inlineContent.text: The
protocol describes how to evolve the current state of an application to the next
state, given an action, and describes what
s should be executed later by the store, if
any. Types that conform to this protocol represent the domain, logic and behavior for a feature.
Conformances to
can be written by hand, but the
can make your reducers
more concise and more powerful.
The bare minimum of conforming to the
protocol is to provide a
type
that represents the state your feature needs to do its job, a
type that
represents the actions users can perform in your feature (as well as actions that effects can
feed back into the system), and a
property that compose your feature
together with any other features that are needed (such as for navigation).
As a very simple example, a ‚Äúcounter‚Äù feature could model its state as a struct holding an integer:
We have added the
to
here so that the view can automatically
observe state changes. In future versions of the library this macro will be automatically applied
by the
macro.
The actions would be just two cases for tapping an increment or decrement button:
The logic of your feature is implemented by mutating the feature‚Äôs current state when an action
comes into the system. This is most easily done by constructing a
inside the
of your reducer:
The
reducer‚Äôs first responsibility is to mutate the feature‚Äôs current state given an
action. Its second responsibility is to return effects that will be executed asynchronously and feed
their data back into the system. Currently
does not need to run any effects, and so
is returned.
If the feature does need to do effectful work, then more would need to be done. For example, suppose
the feature has the ability to start and stop a timer, and with each tick of the timer the
will be incremented. That could be done like so:
This sample emulates a timer by performing an infinite loop with a
inside. This
is simple to do, but is also inaccurate since small imprecisions can accumulate. It would be
better to inject a clock into the feature so that you could use its
method. Read the
and
articles for more information.
That is the basics of implementing a feature as a conformance to
While you technically can conform to the
protocol directly, as we did above, the
macro can automate many aspects of implementing features for you. At a bare minimum,
all you have to do is annotate your reducer with
and you can even drop the
conformance:
There are a number of things the
macro does for you:
The
macro automatically applies the
macro to your
enum:
are a tool that bring the power and ergonomics of key paths to enum
cases, and they are a vital tool for composing reducers together.
In particular, having this macro applied to your
enum will allow you to use key path
syntax for specifying enum cases in various APIs in the library, such as
, and more.
Further, if the
of your feature is an enum, which is useful for modeling a feature
that can be one of multiple mutually exclusive values, the
will apply the
macro, as well as
This will allow you to use key path syntax for specifying case paths to the
‚Äôs cases, as well
as allow you to use dot-chaining syntax for optionally extracting a case from the state. This can be
useful when using the operators that come with the library that allow for driving navigation from an
enum of options:
The syntax
is only possible due to both
and
being applied to the
enum.
The
macro will automatically fill in any
protocol requirements that you
leave off. For example, something as simple as this compiles:
The
macro will automatically insert an empty
struct, an empty
enum, and an empty
. This effectively means that
is a logicless, behaviorless, inert reducer.
Having these requirements automatically fulfilled for you can be handy for slowly filling them in
with their real implementations. For example, this
reducer could be integrated in a parent
domain using the library‚Äôs navigation tools, all without having implemented any of the domain yet.
Then, once we are ready we can start implementing the real logic and behavior of the feature.
There is a common pattern in the Composable Architecture of representing destinations a feature can
navigate to as a reducer that operates on enum state, with a case for each feature that can be
navigated to. This is explained in great detail in the
and
articles.
This form of domain modeling can be very powerful, but also incur a bit of boilerplate. For example,
if a feature can navigate to 3 other features, then one might have a
reducer like the
following:
It‚Äôs not the worst code in the world, but it is 24 lines with a lot of repetition, and if we need to
add a new destination we must add a case to the
enum, a case to the
enum, and a
to the
The
macro is now capable of generating all of this code for you from the following
simple declaration
24 lines of code has become 6. The
macro can now be applied to an
enum
where each case
holds onto the reducer that governs the logic and behavior for that case. Further, when using the
operator with this style of
enum reducer you can
completely leave off the trailing closure as it can be automatically inferred:
This pattern also works for
reducers, which is common when dealing with
, and in that case you can leave off the trailing closure of the
operator:
Further, for
reducers in particular, the
macro also helps you reduce
boilerplate when using the initializer
that comes with the library. In the last
trailing closure you can use the
computed property to switch on the
enum
and extract out a store for each case:
There are many times that you want to present or navigate to a feature that is not modeled with a
Composable Architecture reducer. This can happen with legacy features that are not built with the
Composable Architecture, or with features that are very simple and do not need a fully built
reducer.
In those cases you can use the
and
macros to
annotate cases that are not powered by reducers. See the documentation for those macros for more
details.

content.text: Synthesizing protocol conformances on State and Action

inlineContent.text: Since the
and
types are generated automatically for you when using
on an
enum, it‚Äôs not possible to directly synthesize conformances of
etc.
, on those types. And further, due to a bug in the Swift compiler you cannot currently do
this:
See
below for more info on this error.
So, to work around this compiler bug the
macro takes two
arguments that allow you to describe which
protocols you want to attach to the
or
types:
You can provide any combination of
, or
Applying
can break autocompletion in the
of the reducer. This is a known
, and it can generally be worked around by
providing additional type hints to the compiler:
Adding an explicit
conformance in addition to the macro application can restore
autocomplete throughout the
of the reducer:
Adding explicit generics to instances of
in the
can restore autocomplete
inside the
There is currently a bug in the Swift compiler and macros that prevents you from extending types
that are inside other types with macros applied in the same file. For example, if you wanted to
extend a reducer‚Äôs
with some extra functionality:
This unfortunately does not work. It is a
, and the only workaround is to either
move the extension to a separate file, or move the code from the extension to be directly inside the
type.
The
macro is not capable of seeing the expansion of any macros since it is a macro
itself. This means that when using destination and path reducers (see
above) you cannot construct the cases of the state
enum inside
The
case is not usable from within
since it is generated by the
macro.
The workaround is to move the view to a helper that be compiled outside of a macro, and then use it
inside the macro:
You can use a computed property, free function, or even a dedicated view if you want. You can also
use the old, non-macro style of previews by using a
When testing your code on an external CI server you may run into errors such as the following:
CasePathsMacros Target ‚ÄòCasePathsMacros‚Äô must be enabled before it can be used.
ComposableArchitectureMacros Target ‚ÄòComposableArchitectureMacros‚Äô must be enabled before it can
be used.
You can fix this in one of two ways. You can write a default to the CI machine that allows Xcode to
skip macro validation:
Or if you are invoking
directly in your CI scripts, you can pass the
flag to
when building your project:

abstract.text: Learn about one of the most fundamental tools in the Composable Architecture: the reducer. It is
responsible for evolving the state of your application forward when an action is sent, and
constructing effects that are executed in the outside world.
A destructurable view of a store on a collection of cases.
A type that holds the current state of the reducer.
Learn about tree-based navigation, that is navigation modeled with optionals and enums, including
how to model your domains, how to integrate features, how to test your features, and more.
Embeds a child reducer in a parent domain that works on elements of a navigation stack in
A type-erased reducer that invokes the given
Learn techniques for sharing state throughout many parts of your application, and how to persist
data to user defaults, the file system, and other external mediums.
A type that holds all possible actions that cause the
that can communicate with the outside world.
A protocol that describes how to evolve the current state of an application to the next state,
given an action, and describes what
s should be executed later by the store, if any.
Learn about stack-based navigation, that is navigation modeled with collections, including how to
model your domains, how to integrate features, how to test your features, and more.
Defines and implements conformance of the Observable protocol.
A description of a protocol conformance to synthesize on the State and Action types
Helps implement the conformance to the
An effect that does nothing and completes immediately. Useful for situations where you must
return an effect, but you don‚Äôt need to do anything.
Learn how to register dependencies with the library so that they can be immediately accessible from
The Composable Architecture (TCA, for short) is a library for building applications in a consistent
and understandable way, with composition, testing, and ergonomics in mind. It can be used in
SwiftUI, UIKit, and more, and on any Apple platform (iOS, macOS, tvOS, and watchOS).
A store represents the runtime that powers the application. It is the object that you will pass
around to views that need to interact with the application.
The content and behavior of a reducer that is composed from other reducers.
Marks the case of an enum reducer as holding onto ‚Äúephemeral‚Äù state.
Embeds a child reducer in a parent domain.

#Synthesizing-protocol-conformances-on-S.title: Synthesizing protocol conformances on State and Action

abstract.text: Embeds a child reducer in a parent domain that works on an optional property of parent state.
Learn how to write comprehensive and exhaustive tests for your features built in the Composable
Drives a navigation stack with a store.
Marks the case of an enum reducer as ‚Äúignored‚Äù, and as such will not compose the case‚Äôs
domain into the rest of the reducer besides state.
